Chapter 5.5:1: One day Jesus was standing on the shore of Lake Gennesaret while the people pushed their way up to him to listen to the word of God.

Chapter 5.5:2: He saw two boats pulled up on the beach; the fishermen had left them and were washing the nets.

Chapter 5.5:3: Jesus got into one of the boats—it belonged to Simon—and asked him to push off a little from the shore. Jesus sat in the boat and taught the crowd.

Chapter 5.5:4: When he finished speaking, he said to Simon, Push the boat out further to the deep water, and you and your partners let down your nets for a catch.

Chapter 5.5:5: Master, Simon answered, we worked hard all night long and caught nothing. But if you say so, I will let down the nets.

Chapter 5.5:6: They let them down and caught such a large number of fish that the nets were about to break.

Chapter 5.5:7: So they motioned to their partners in the other boat to come and help them. They came and filled both boats so full of fish that the boats were about to sink.

Chapter 5.5:8: When Simon Peter saw what had happened, he fell on his knees before Jesus and said, Go away from me, Lord! I am a sinful man!

Chapter 5.5:9: He and the others with him were all amazed at the large number of fish they had caught.

Chapter 5.5:10: The same was true of Simon's partners, James and John, the sons of Zebedee. Jesus said to Simon, Don't be afraid; from now on you will be catching people.

Chapter 5.5:11: They pulled the boats up on the beach, left everything, and followed Jesus.

Chapter 5.5:12: Once Jesus was in a town where there was a man who was suffering from a dreaded skin disease. When he saw Jesus, he threw himself down and begged him, Sir, if you want to, you can make me clean!

Chapter 5.5:13: Jesus reached out and touched him. I do want to, he answered. Be clean! At once the disease left the man.

Chapter 5.5:14: Jesus ordered him, Don't tell anyone, but go straight to the priest and let him examine you; then to prove to everyone that you are cured, offer the sacrifice as Moses ordered.

Chapter 5.5:15: But the news about Jesus spread all the more widely, and crowds of people came to hear him and be healed from their diseases.

Chapter 5.5:16: But he would go away to lonely places, where he prayed.

Chapter 5.5:17: One day when Jesus was teaching, some Pharisees and teachers of the Law were sitting there who had come from every town in Galilee and Judea and from Jerusalem. The power of the Lord was present for Jesus to heal the sick.

Chapter 5.5:18: Some men came carrying a paralyzed man on a bed, and they tried to carry him into the house and put him in front of Jesus.

Chapter 5.5:19: Because of the crowd, however, they could find no way to take him in. So they carried him up on the roof, made an opening in the tiles, and let him down on his bed into the middle of the group in front of Jesus.

Chapter 5.5:20: When Jesus saw how much faith they had, he said to the man, Your sins are forgiven, my friend.

Chapter 5.5:21: The teachers of the Law and the Pharisees began to say to themselves, Who is this man who speaks such blasphemy! God is the only one who can forgive sins!

Chapter 5.5:22: Jesus knew their thoughts and said to them, Why do you think such things?

Chapter 5.5:23: Is it easier to say, Your sins are forgiven you, or to say, Get up and walk?

Chapter 5.5:24: I will prove to you, then, that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins. So he said to the paralyzed man, I tell you, get up, pick up your bed, and go home!

Chapter 5.5:25: At once the man got up in front of them all, took the bed he had been lying on, and went home, praising God.

Chapter 5.5:26: They were all completely amazed! Full of fear, they praised God, saying, What marvelous things we have seen today!

Chapter 5.5:27: After this, Jesus went out and saw a tax collector named Levi, sitting in his office. Jesus said to him, Follow me.

Chapter 5.5:28: Levi got up, left everything, and followed him.

Chapter 5.5:29: Then Levi had a big feast in his house for Jesus, and among the guests was a large number of tax collectors and other people.

Chapter 5.5:30: Some Pharisees and some teachers of the Law who belonged to their group complained to Jesus' disciples. Why do you eat and drink with tax collectors and other outcasts? they asked.

Chapter 5.5:31: Jesus answered them, People who are well do not need a doctor, but only those who are sick.

Chapter 5.5:32: I have not come to call respectable people to repent, but outcasts.

Chapter 5.5:33: Some people said to Jesus, The disciples of John fast frequently and offer prayers, and the disciples of the Pharisees do the same; but your disciples eat and drink.

Chapter 5.5:34: Jesus answered, Do you think you can make the guests at a wedding party go without food as long as the bridegroom is with them? Of course not!

Chapter 5.5:35: But the day will come when the bridegroom will be taken away from them, and then they will fast.

Chapter 5.5:36: Jesus also told them this parable: You don't tear a piece off a new coat to patch up an old coat. If you do, you will have torn the new coat, and the piece of new cloth will not match the old.

Chapter 5.5:37: Nor do you pour new wine into used wineskins, because the new wine will burst the skins, the wine will pour out, and the skins will be ruined.

Chapter 5.5:38: Instead, new wine must be poured into fresh wineskins!

Chapter 5.5:39: And you don't want new wine after drinking old wine. The old is better, you say.

Chapter 7.7:1: When Jesus had finished saying all these things to the people, he went to Capernaum.

Chapter 7.7:2: A Roman officer there had a servant who was very dear to him; the man was sick and about to die.

Chapter 7.7:3: When the officer heard about Jesus, he sent some Jewish elders to ask him to come and heal his servant.

Chapter 7.7:4: They came to Jesus and begged him earnestly, This man really deserves your help.

Chapter 7.7:5: He loves our people and he himself built a synagogue for us.

Chapter 7.7:6: So Jesus went with them. He was not far from the house when the officer sent friends to tell him, Sir, don't trouble yourself. I do not deserve to have you come into my house,

Chapter 7.7:7: neither do I consider myself worthy to come to you in person. Just give the order, and my servant will get well.

Chapter 7.7:8: I, too, am a man placed under the authority of superior officers, and I have soldiers under me. I order this one, Go! and he goes; I order that one, Come! and he comes; and I order my slave, Do this! and he does it.

Chapter 7.7:9: Jesus was surprised when he heard this; he turned around and said to the crowd following him, I tell you, I have never found faith like this, not even in Israel!

Chapter 7.7:10: The messengers went back to the officer's house and found his servant well.

Chapter 7.7:11: Soon afterward Jesus went to a town named Nain, accompanied by his disciples and a large crowd.

Chapter 7.7:12: Just as he arrived at the gate of the town, a funeral procession was coming out. The dead man was the only son of a woman who was a widow, and a large crowd from the town was with her.

Chapter 7.7:13: When the Lord saw her, his heart was filled with pity for her, and he said to her, Don't cry.

Chapter 7.7:14: Then he walked over and touched the coffin, and the men carrying it stopped. Jesus said, Young man! Get up, I tell you!

Chapter 7.7:15: The dead man sat up and began to talk, and Jesus gave him back to his mother.

Chapter 7.7:16: They all were filled with fear and praised God. A great prophet has appeared among us! they said; God has come to save his people!

Chapter 7.7:17: This news about Jesus went out through all the country and the surrounding territory.

Chapter 7.7:18: When John's disciples told him about all these things, he called two of them

Chapter 7.7:19: and sent them to the Lord to ask him, Are you the one John said was going to come, or should we expect someone else?

Chapter 7.7:20: When they came to Jesus, they said, John the Baptist sent us to ask if you are the one he said was going to come, or should we expect someone else?

Chapter 7.7:21: At that very time Jesus healed many people from their sicknesses, diseases, and evil spirits, and gave sight to many blind people.

Chapter 7.7:22: He answered John's messengers, Go back and tell John what you have seen and heard: the blind can see, the lame can walk, those who suffer from dreaded skin diseases are made clean, the deaf can hear, the dead are raised to life, and the Good News is preached to the poor.

Chapter 7.7:23: How happy are those who have no doubts about me!

Chapter 7.7:24: After John's messengers had left, Jesus began to speak about him to the crowds: When you went out to John in the desert, what did you expect to see? A blade of grass bending in the wind?

Chapter 7.7:25: What did you go out to see? A man dressed up in fancy clothes? People who dress like that and live in luxury are found in palaces!

Chapter 7.7:26: Tell me, what did you go out to see? A prophet? Yes indeed, but you saw much more than a prophet.

Chapter 7.7:27: For John is the one of whom the scripture says: God said, I will send my messenger ahead of you to open the way for you.

Chapter 7.7:28: I tell you, Jesus added, John is greater than anyone who has ever lived. But the one who is least in the Kingdom of God is greater than John.

Chapter 7.7:29: All the people heard him; they and especially the tax collectors were the ones who had obeyed God's righteous demands and had been baptized by John.

Chapter 7.7:30: But the Pharisees and the teachers of the Law rejected God's purpose for themselves and refused to be baptized by John.

Chapter 7.7:31: Jesus continued, Now to what can I compare the people of this day? What are they like?

Chapter 7.7:32: They are like children sitting in the marketplace. One group shouts to the other, We played wedding music for you, but you wouldn't dance! We sang funeral songs, but you wouldn't cry!

Chapter 7.7:33: John the Baptist came, and he fasted and drank no wine, and you said, He has a demon in him!

Chapter 7.7:34: The Son of Man came, and he ate and drank, and you said, Look at this man! He is a glutton and wine drinker, a friend of tax collectors and other outcasts!

Chapter 7.7:35: God's wisdom, however, is shown to be true by all who accept it.

Chapter 7.7:36: A Pharisee invited Jesus to have dinner with him, and Jesus went to his house and sat down to eat.

Chapter 7.7:37: In that town was a woman who lived a sinful life. She heard that Jesus was eating in the Pharisee's house, so she brought an alabaster jar full of perfume

Chapter 7.7:38: and stood behind Jesus, by his feet, crying and wetting his feet with her tears. Then she dried his feet with her hair, kissed them, and poured the perfume on them.

Chapter 7.7:39: When the Pharisee saw this, he said to himself, If this man really were a prophet, he would know who this woman is who is touching him; he would know what kind of sinful life she lives!

Chapter 7.7:40: Jesus spoke up and said to him, Simon, I have something to tell you. Yes, Teacher, he said, tell me.

Chapter 7.7:41: There were two men who owed money to a moneylender, Jesus began. One owed him five hundred silver coins, and the other owed him fifty.

Chapter 7.7:42: Neither of them could pay him back, so he canceled the debts of both. Which one, then, will love him more?

Chapter 7.7:43: I suppose, answered Simon, that it would be the one who was forgiven more. You are right, said Jesus.

Chapter 7.7:44: Then he turned to the woman and said to Simon, Do you see this woman? I came into your home, and you gave me no water for my feet, but she has washed my feet with her tears and dried them with her hair.

Chapter 7.7:45: You did not welcome me with a kiss, but she has not stopped kissing my feet since I came.

Chapter 7.7:46: You provided no olive oil for my head, but she has covered my feet with perfume.

Chapter 7.7:47: I tell you, then, the great love she has shown proves that her many sins have been forgiven. But whoever has been forgiven little shows only a little love.

Chapter 7.7:48: Then Jesus said to the woman, Your sins are forgiven.

Chapter 7.7:49: The others sitting at the table began to say to themselves, Who is this, who even forgives sins?

Chapter 7.7:50: But Jesus said to the woman, Your faith has saved you; go in peace.

Chapter 8.8:1: Some time later Jesus traveled through towns and villages, preaching the Good News about the Kingdom of God. The twelve disciples went with him,

Chapter 8.8:2: and so did some women who had been healed of evil spirits and diseases: Mary who was called Magdalene, from whom seven demons had been driven out;

Chapter 8.8:3: Joanna, whose husband Chuza was an officer in Herod's court; and Susanna, and many other women who used their own resources to help Jesus and his disciples.

Chapter 8.8:4: People kept coming to Jesus from one town after another; and when a great crowd gathered, Jesus told this parable:

Chapter 8.8:5: Once there was a man who went out to sow grain. As he scattered the seed in the field, some of it fell along the path, where it was stepped on, and the birds ate it up.

Chapter 8.8:6: Some of it fell on rocky ground, and when the plants sprouted, they dried up because the soil had no moisture.

Chapter 8.8:7: Some of the seed fell among thorn bushes, which grew up with the plants and choked them.

Chapter 8.8:8: And some seeds fell in good soil; the plants grew and bore grain, one hundred grains each. And Jesus concluded, Listen, then, if you have ears!

Chapter 8.8:9: His disciples asked Jesus what this parable meant,

Chapter 8.8:10: and he answered, The knowledge of the secrets of the Kingdom of God has been given to you, but to the rest it comes by means of parables, so that they may look but not see, and listen but not understand.

Chapter 8.8:11: This is what the parable means: the seed is the word of God.

Chapter 8.8:12: The seeds that fell along the path stand for those who hear; but the Devil comes and takes the message away from their hearts in order to keep them from believing and being saved.

Chapter 8.8:13: The seeds that fell on rocky ground stand for those who hear the message and receive it gladly. But it does not sink deep into them; they believe only for a while but when the time of testing comes, they fall away.

Chapter 8.8:14: The seeds that fell among thorn bushes stand for those who hear; but the worries and riches and pleasures of this life crowd in and choke them, and their fruit never ripens.

Chapter 8.8:15: The seeds that fell in good soil stand for those who hear the message and retain it in a good and obedient heart, and they persist until they bear fruit.

Chapter 8.8:16: No one lights a lamp and covers it with a bowl or puts it under a bed. Instead, it is put on the lampstand, so that people will see the light as they come in.

Chapter 8.8:17: Whatever is hidden away will be brought out into the open, and whatever is covered up will be found and brought to light.

Chapter 8.8:18: Be careful, then, how you listen; because those who have something will be given more, but whoever has nothing will have taken away from them even the little they think they have.

Chapter 8.8:19: Jesus' mother and brothers came to him, but were unable to join him because of the crowd.

Chapter 8.8:20: Someone said to Jesus, Your mother and brothers are standing outside and want to see you.

Chapter 8.8:21: Jesus said to them all, My mother and brothers are those who hear the word of God and obey it.

Chapter 8.8:22: One day Jesus got into a boat with his disciples and said to them, Let us go across to the other side of the lake. So they started out.

Chapter 8.8:23: As they were sailing, Jesus fell asleep. Suddenly a strong wind blew down on the lake, and the boat began to fill with water, so that they were all in great danger.

Chapter 8.8:24: The disciples went to Jesus and woke him up, saying, Master, Master! We are about to die! Jesus got up and gave an order to the wind and to the stormy water; they quieted down, and there was a great calm.

Chapter 8.8:25: Then he said to the disciples, Where is your faith? But they were amazed and afraid, and said to one another, Who is this man? He gives orders to the winds and waves, and they obey him!

Chapter 8.8:26: Jesus and his disciples sailed on over to the territory of Gerasa, which is across the lake from Galilee.

Chapter 8.8:27: As Jesus stepped ashore, he was met by a man from the town who had demons in him. For a long time this man had gone without clothes and would not stay at home, but spent his time in the burial caves.

Chapter 8.8:28: When he saw Jesus, he gave a loud cry, threw himself down at his feet, and shouted, Jesus, Son of the Most High God! What do you want with me? I beg you, don't punish me!

Chapter 8.8:29: He said this because Jesus had ordered the evil spirit to go out of him. Many times it had seized him, and even though he was kept a prisoner, his hands and feet tied with chains, he would break the chains and be driven by the demon out into the desert.

Chapter 8.8:31: The demons begged Jesus not to send them into the abyss.

Chapter 8.8:32: There was a large herd of pigs near by, feeding on a hillside. So the demons begged Jesus to let them go into the pigs, and he let them.

Chapter 8.8:33: They went out of the man and into the pigs. The whole herd rushed down the side of the cliff into the lake and was drowned.

Chapter 8.8:34: The men who had been taking care of the pigs saw what happened, so they ran off and spread the news in the town and among the farms.

Chapter 8.8:37: Then all the people from that territory asked Jesus to go away, because they were terribly afraid. So Jesus got into the boat and left.

Chapter 8.8:38: The man from whom the demons had gone out begged Jesus, Let me go with you. But Jesus sent him away, saying,

Chapter 8.8:40: When Jesus returned to the other side of the lake, the people welcomed him, because they had all been waiting for him.

Chapter 8.8:47: The woman saw that she had been found out, so she came trembling and threw herself at Jesus' feet. There in front of everybody, she told him why she had touched him and how she had been healed at once.

Chapter 8.8:48: Jesus said to her, My daughter, your faith has made you well. Go in peace.

Chapter 8.8:50: But Jesus heard it and said to Jairus, Don't be afraid; only believe, and she will be well.

Chapter 8.8:51: When he arrived at the house, he would not let anyone go in with him except Peter, John, and James, and the child's father and mother.

Chapter 8.8:54: But Jesus took her by the hand and called out, Get up, child!

Chapter 8.8:55: Her life returned, and she got up at once, and Jesus ordered them to give her something to eat.

Chapter 8.8:56: Her parents were astounded, but Jesus commanded them not to tell anyone what had happened.

Chapter 10.10:13: How terrible it will be for you, Chorazin! How terrible for you too, Bethsaida! If the miracles which were performed in you had been performed in Tyre and Sidon, the people there would have long ago sat down, put on sackcloth, and sprinkled ashes on themselves, to show that they had turned from their sins!

Chapter 10.10:33: But a Samaritan who was traveling that way came upon the man, and when he saw him, his heart was filled with pity.

Chapter 12.12:1: As thousands of people crowded together, so that they were stepping on each other, Jesus said first to his disciples, Be on guard against the yeast of the Pharisees—I mean their hypocrisy.

Chapter 12.12:17: He began to think to himself, I don't have a place to keep all my crops. What can I do?

Chapter 12.12:19: Then I will say to myself, Lucky man! You have all the good things you need for many years. Take life easy, eat, drink, and enjoy yourself!

Chapter 12.12:20: But God said to him, You fool! This very night you will have to give up your life; then who will get all these things you have kept for yourself?

Chapter 12.12:21: And Jesus concluded, This is how it is with those who pile up riches for themselves but are not rich in God's sight.

Chapter 12.12:22: Then Jesus said to the disciples, And so I tell you not to worry about the food you need to stay alive or about the clothes you need for your body.

Chapter 12.12:23: Life is much more important than food, and the body much more important than clothes.

Chapter 12.12:24: Look at the crows: they don't plant seeds or gather a harvest; they don't have storage rooms or barns; God feeds them! You are worth so much more than birds!

Chapter 12.12:25: Can any of you live a bit longer by worrying about it?

Chapter 12.12:26: If you can't manage even such a small thing, why worry about the other things?

Chapter 12.12:27: Look how the wild flowers grow: they don't work or make clothes for themselves. But I tell you that not even King Solomon with all his wealth had clothes as beautiful as one of these flowers.

Chapter 12.12:28: It is God who clothes the wild grass—grass that is here today and gone tomorrow, burned up in the oven. Won't he be all the more sure to clothe you? What little faith you have!

Chapter 12.12:29: So don't be all upset, always concerned about what you will eat and drink.

Chapter 12.12:30: For the pagans of this world are always concerned about all these things. Your Father knows that you need these things.

Chapter 12.12:32: Do not be afraid, little flock, for your Father is pleased to give you the Kingdom.

Chapter 12.12:48: But the servant who does not know what his master wants, and yet does something for which he deserves a whipping, will be punished with a light whipping. Much is required from the person to whom much is given; much more is required from the person to whom much more is given.

Chapter 13.13:1: At that time some people were there who told Jesus about the Galileans whom Pilate had killed while they were offering sacrifices to God.

Chapter 16.16:1: Jesus said to his disciples, There was once a rich man who had a servant who managed his property. The rich man was told that the manager was wasting his master's money,

Chapter 18.18:1: Then Jesus told his disciples a parable to teach them that they should always pray and never become discouraged.

Chapter 21.21:1: Jesus looked around and saw rich people dropping their gifts in the Temple treasury,

Chapter 22.22:61: The Lord turned around and looked straight at Peter, and Peter remembered that the Lord had said to him, Before the rooster crows tonight, you will say three times that you do not know me.

Chapter 22.22:62: Peter went out and wept bitterly.

Chapter 22.22:63: The men who were guarding Jesus made fun of him and beat him.

Chapter 22.22:64: They blindfolded him and asked him, Who hit you? Guess!

Chapter 22.22:65: And they said many other insulting things to him.

Chapter 22.22:66: When day came, the elders, the chief priests, and the teachers of the Law met together, and Jesus was brought before the Council.

Chapter 22.22:67: Tell us, they said, are you the Messiah? He answered, If I tell you, you will not believe me;

Chapter 22.22:68: and if I ask you a question, you will not answer.

Chapter 22.22:69: But from now on the Son of Man will be seated at the right side of Almighty God.

Chapter 22.22:70: They all said, Are you, then, the Son of God? He answered them, You say that I am.

Chapter 22.22:71: And they said, We don't need any witnesses! We ourselves have heard what he said!

Chapter 23.23:1: The whole group rose up and took Jesus before Pilate,

Chapter 23.23:2: where they began to accuse him: We caught this man misleading our people, telling them not to pay taxes to the Emperor and claiming that he himself is the Messiah, a king.

Chapter 23.23:3: Pilate asked him, Are you the king of the Jews? So you say, answered Jesus.

Chapter 23.23:4: Then Pilate said to the chief priests and the crowds, I find no reason to condemn this man.

Chapter 23.23:5: But they insisted even more strongly, With his teaching he is starting a riot among the people all through Judea. He began in Galilee and now has come here.

Chapter 23.23:6: When Pilate heard this, he asked, Is this man a Galilean?

Chapter 23.23:7: When he learned that Jesus was from the region ruled by Herod, he sent him to Herod, who was also in Jerusalem at that time.

Chapter 23.23:8: Herod was very pleased when he saw Jesus, because he had heard about him and had been wanting to see him for a long time. He was hoping to see Jesus perform some miracle.

Chapter 23.23:9: So Herod asked Jesus many questions, but Jesus made no answer.

Chapter 23.23:10: The chief priests and the teachers of the Law stepped forward and made strong accusations against Jesus.

Chapter 23.23:11: Herod and his soldiers made fun of Jesus and treated him with contempt; then they put a fine robe on him and sent him back to Pilate.

Chapter 23.23:12: On that very day Herod and Pilate became friends; before this they had been enemies.

Chapter 23.23:13: Pilate called together the chief priests, the leaders, and the people,

Chapter 23.23:14: and said to them, You brought this man to me and said that he was misleading the people. Now, I have examined him here in your presence, and I have not found him guilty of any of the crimes you accuse him of.

Chapter 23.23:15: Nor did Herod find him guilty, for he sent him back to us. There is nothing this man has done to deserve death.

Chapter 23.23:16: So I will have him whipped and let him go.

Chapter 23.23:18: The whole crowd cried out, Kill him! Set Barabbas free for us!

Chapter 23.23:19: Barabbas had been put in prison for a riot that had taken place in the city, and for murder.

Chapter 23.23:20: Pilate wanted to set Jesus free, so he appealed to the crowd again.

Chapter 23.23:21: But they shouted back, Crucify him! Crucify him!

Chapter 23.23:22: Pilate said to them the third time, But what crime has he committed? I cannot find anything he has done to deserve death! I will have him whipped and set him free.

Chapter 23.23:23: But they kept on shouting at the top of their voices that Jesus should be crucified, and finally their shouting succeeded.

Chapter 23.23:24: So Pilate passed the sentence on Jesus that they were asking for.

Chapter 23.23:25: He set free the man they wanted, the one who had been put in prison for riot and murder, and he handed Jesus over for them to do as they wished.

Chapter 23.23:26: The soldiers led Jesus away, and as they were going, they met a man from Cyrene named Simon who was coming into the city from the country. They seized him, put the cross on him, and made him carry it behind Jesus.

Chapter 23.23:27: A large crowd of people followed him; among them were some women who were weeping and wailing for him.

Chapter 23.23:28: Jesus turned to them and said, Women of Jerusalem! Don't cry for me, but for yourselves and your children.

Chapter 23.23:29: For the days are coming when people will say, How lucky are the women who never had children, who never bore babies, who never nursed them!

Chapter 23.23:30: That will be the time when people will say to the mountains, Fall on us! and to the hills, Hide us!

Chapter 23.23:31: For if such things as these are done when the wood is green, what will happen when it is dry?

Chapter 23.23:32: Two other men, both of them criminals, were also led out to be put to death with Jesus.

Chapter 23.23:33: When they came to the place called The Skull, they crucified Jesus there, and the two criminals, one on his right and the other on his left.

Chapter 23.23:34: Jesus said, Forgive them, Father! They don't know what they are doing. They divided his clothes among themselves by throwing dice.

Chapter 23.23:35: The people stood there watching while the Jewish leaders made fun of him: He saved others; let him save himself if he is the Messiah whom God has chosen!

Chapter 23.23:36: The soldiers also made fun of him: they came up to him and offered him cheap wine,

Chapter 23.23:37: and said, Save yourself if you are the king of the Jews!

Chapter 23.23:38: Above him were written these words: This is the King of the Jews.

Chapter 23.23:39: One of the criminals hanging there hurled insults at him: Aren't you the Messiah? Save yourself and us!

Chapter 23.23:40: The other one, however, rebuked him, saying, Don't you fear God? You received the same sentence he did.

Chapter 23.23:41: Ours, however, is only right, because we are getting what we deserve for what we did; but he has done no wrong.

Chapter 23.23:42: And he said to Jesus, Remember me, Jesus, when you come as King!

Chapter 23.23:43: Jesus said to him, I promise you that today you will be in Paradise with me.

Chapter 23.23:45: 44-It was about twelve o'clock when the sun stopped shining and darkness covered the whole country until three o'clock; and the curtain hanging in the Temple was torn in two.

Chapter 23.23:46: Jesus cried out in a loud voice, Father! In your hands I place my spirit! He said this and died.

Chapter 23.23:47: The army officer saw what had happened, and he praised God, saying, Certainly he was a good man!

Chapter 23.23:48: When the people who had gathered there to watch the spectacle saw what happened, they all went back home, beating their breasts in sorrow.

Chapter 23.23:49: All those who knew Jesus personally, including the women who had followed him from Galilee, stood at a distance to watch.

Chapter 23.23:51: 50-There was a man named Joseph from Arimathea, a town in Judea. He was a good and honorable man, who was waiting for the coming of the Kingdom of God. Although he was a member of the Council, he had not agreed with their decision and action.

Chapter 23.23:52: He went into the presence of Pilate and asked for the body of Jesus.

Chapter 23.23:53: Then he took the body down, wrapped it in a linen sheet, and placed it in a tomb which had been dug out of solid rock and which had never been used.

Chapter 23.23:54: It was Friday, and the Sabbath was about to begin.

Chapter 23.23:55: The women who had followed Jesus from Galilee went with Joseph and saw the tomb and how Jesus' body was placed in it.

Chapter 23.23:56: Then they went back home and prepared the spices and perfumes for the body. On the Sabbath they rested, as the Law commanded.

Chapter 24.24:1: Very early on Sunday morning the women went to the tomb, carrying the spices they had prepared.

Chapter 24.24:3: so they went in; but they did not find the body of the Lord Jesus.

Chapter 24.24:4: They stood there puzzled about this, when suddenly two men in bright shining clothes stood by them.

Chapter 24.24:5: Full of fear, the women bowed down to the ground, as the men said to them, Why are you looking among the dead for one who is alive?

Chapter 24.24:6: He is not here; he has been raised. Remember what he said to you while he was in Galilee:

Chapter 24.24:7: The Son of Man must be handed over to sinners, be crucified, and three days later rise to life.

Chapter 24.24:8: Then the women remembered his words,

Chapter 24.24:9: returned from the tomb, and told all these things to the eleven disciples and all the rest.

Chapter 24.24:10: The women were Mary Magdalene, Joanna, and Mary the mother of James; they and the other women with them told these things to the apostles.

Chapter 24.24:14: and they were talking to each other about all the things that had happened.

Chapter 24.24:15: As they talked and discussed, Jesus himself drew near and walked along with them;

Chapter 24.24:17: Jesus said to them, What are you talking about to each other, as you walk along? They stood still, with sad faces.

Chapter 24.24:18: One of them, named Cleopas, asked him, Are you the only visitor in Jerusalem who doesn't know the things that have been happening there these last few days?

Chapter 24.24:19: What things? he asked. The things that happened to Jesus of Nazareth, they answered. This man was a prophet and was considered by God and by all the people to be powerful in everything he said and did.

Chapter 24.24:20: Our chief priests and rulers handed him over to be sentenced to death, and he was crucified.
